review_title: Wells Fargo is more than just tellers.
pros:
Wells Fargo is a company that has absolutely shown it's strengths during the current economic downturn.  Issues that might have been considered downsides only a year ago are now looked at as a positive trait.  One such trait is the slow delibrate hiring process.  In the past this was a source of frustration, now I see that because of this we were not significantly overstaffed when the downturn hit.  We have had to make very few adjustments in staffing overall and Wells Fargo even instituted a early hiring freeze in order to make way for the inevitable overlap with Wachovia.  

Overall this is a positive place to work if you keep in mind the restrictions that large companies operate within.
cons:
The focus on the Wells Fargo brand as perceived by corporate is a bit tough sometimes.  A brand that was more current would be much appreciated by many.  Because their are so many business lines (84 seperate products/services in Commercial Banking alone) it can be hard to grasp the pure volume of data within the company.  A better knowledge management solution would be a good start.  

Additionally, because there is such internal opportunity for growth we have quite a few layers of upper management that do not have direct experience in the areas of business they manage.  bringing in outside expertise would not be a horrible idea in some areas.

review_title: Everything sounds and seems perfectly wonderful at first, then you're reminded that there's trouble in Paradise.

Your working environment changes from branch to branch. It's almost as if each branch is it's own city within the same state in that, all the local branches work under the same Policy & Procedures, and yet things are just done differently. Compare the city of Miami to Mayo. The company values are simple, do as you're told, obey the rules, be honest and your reward is you keep your job. Then again, if you don't do these things... Just don't get caught and you can still keep your job.
cons: Promotion exceptions are constantly made, rarely consistent, and favor based. You'll find who you know is more important than what you know. You're told that you're all apart of a team, and that you're Teammates. Yet you're also told you can't trust anyone, which is true, DON'T. It's super easy to make enemies, get fired, or go crazy from it all and quit.

review_title: A great opportunity IF you are a sales-oriented person
pros: Wells Fargo is a large company that one could move up and/ or around in if (s)he seeks a career in the financial services industry and is very sales-oriented. The benefits given to employees are very good such as your insurance, retirement, and a myriad of other financial perks you get by working at a bank. It is also a company that values diversity and tries to reach out to minority demographic groups--especially the growing Latino population in the United States. If you know Spanish or any another language this company is likely to value your language skills and cross-cultural competency.
cons: Wells Fargo is a great opportunity for you if--and I mean IF--you are a very sales-oriented person. For example, as a teller your job is not simply to provide efficient, accurate and courteous service to the bank's accountholders as one might think. As a teller you are NOT simply working in customer service. You ARE working in an entry-level sales position. You have a sales quota to meet every quarter and if you consistently do not meet your quota you will no longer be employed by Wells Fargo. It is as simple as that. If your personality is not geared toward trying to convince a customer who merely wanted to come in and quickly cash their check why they should get a credit card, open another account, or use some other financial service, then this job is clearly not meant for you. Be able to suceed at giving a rapid-fire sales pitch or you will not make it.

pros: The benefits are great and there is plenty of positions available to move anywhere you want to go. At my branch in particular, we all get along like a big happy family, although I have heard other branches are a bit rough to work at.
cons: They will fire you without hesitation no matter how great of an employee you are in all other areas if you don't meet minimum sales requirements. It's always bugged me that they call tellers "sales positions" when they aren't. Tellers are the middle-men between a banker and a sale. There is no way for a teller to make a direct sale and all referrals must be sent to a banker, the banker must contact the customer, and the customer must agree and have time to come in to make the sale final. After all this, the teller might not get credit for the sale because another teller might have tracked a customer 45 days or less before the other teller, thus credit goes to the first teller to ever track the customer, regardless of the reasoning behind each teller's tracking. The biggest issue is Wells Fargo beating to death their tellers with sales when they can't make sales themselves, it all has to be referred to someone else to close anything.

The major reason for the 3-star rating was the discrepancy in the different departments. I started in loan origination - working on purchase and refinance mortgages. They (management) would bring in lunch/dinner on a weekly basis, have team outings, and were very active in maintaining morale among the teams. These efforts made it much more pleasurable to work there, and made me feel that they really did practice what they preached with caring about the employees.

Then I was moved to Home Preservation department. Since this department does not directly make a profit for the company, all of the above-mentioned extras vanished. in over a year and a half, we were given lunch/dinner 2 times, had no team outings, and there were no efforts to promote positive morale and feelings in the work environment.

Such a huge disappointment as I was doing essentially the same job and had the exact same job title in both positions. Such a severe discrepancy in how the employees were treated and valued is hard to accept.

Ultimately I would recommend this company as a place to work, but with the caveat of avoiding non-profitable departments.

Wells Fargo is not for individuals who are not sales oriented. No matter what position you take on in a retail branch, you're a salesman. Wells Fargo has strict expectations for maintaining metrics of threshold standard and above.  If you've worked for smaller banks and or Credit Unions, this is nothing like it. The two largest issues I have are the commission pay out, that it's around 3,000 per quarter, and that's if you're a top performer, and that there is an astronomical turn over rate across the board from DM's to tellers.

The point was they would really push very aggressively to the teller and bankers to meet those goals and teach the bankers and tellers to push products on the customers even when sometimes they didn't really needed and there was no benefit to the customer for having the product. job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good benefits, not too stressful (depends on job though), strong financials, opportunities for advancement. Working for a bank gets you good deals on credit cards and mortgages! Tuition reimbursement always helps too.
cons: Company is too big, management is way too far removed from employees. My department had a severe lack of recognition (I once got a bag of M&Ms as a year end thank you, while friends at other companies got big bonuses!). Pay is low relative to market, although that has changed for some departments since the merger with Wachovia (actually it wasn't a merger, we bought them out). Another thing is that since the merger there has been a clash of cultures between legacy Wells and legacy Wachovia. A lot of Wells people lost their jobs to less qualified people on the Wachovia side, and the Wachovia folks have a real attitude problem. This is seen all throughout the bank. Wells also increasingly strayed from my personal values as time went on. Also, the company is too spread out, preventing company gatherings on a broader level. You basically never get a chance to meet people in other departments unless you work with them.

job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great pay, especially considering lack of experience upon entering company. Many opportunities for bonuses and advancement. Loan processing is a pretty simple job when the workload is average. So many other perks depending on how fun your manager is such as many free meals from good restaurants, company outings (that are much more fun than it sounds), free products from Wells Fargo and affiliates every once in a while, access to company sponsored events, numerous discounts from programs offered by other companies like best buy, target, apple, IBM, etc. the list goes on.
cons: Policy changes are massive and often. Decisions are made so far above your manager's head by people that have no connection to your actual job duties, so that when these changes inevitably complicate your job further, there's no point in discussing them. You just have to roll with the punches. Also, while decisions for promotion and bonuses are usually made by your manager or his/her manager, decisions for layoffs are made at that same ethereal level where even the person that basically runs the entire building you work in has no say. When your time is up, it's simply up. Also there's not a whole lot of job security in the mortgage department but that's hardly their fault.

Career progress appears limited and slow. Promotions virtually non existent. People sitting in the same role for long- easily 5+ years with no upward trajectory.

pros: Coworkers are high caliber, great variety of big impact projects, all the mainstream technologies, and lots of innovative ones  being considered.  Very flexible time, ample PTO, etc.  I would recommend a job here on a short term or contract basis.
cons: There is no such thing as a career at Wells Fargo due to the constant reorgs.  If you are seeking a career in terms of getting a promotion and in turn higher pay, stay away.  If you want to gain valuable project experience and use it to get a promotion elsewhere, then join Wells Fargo, but make sure you leave.  The only opportunity to advance is by applying elsewhere in the company, but that is really like applying to a new company - there is no fast tracking as an existing employee.  Training is nonexistent for the workers, but management is quick to go to conferences themselves.
